    "let @xmath0 be the ring of laurent polynomial in an indeterminate @xmath1 with integer coefficients .",
    "suppose @xmath2 is an oriented surface .",
    "the kauffman bracket skein algebra @xmath3 is a @xmath0-algebra generated by unoriented framed links in @xmath4 $ ] subject the kauffman skein relations @xcite which are recalled in section [ sec : prelim ] .",
    "the skein algebras were introduced by przyticki @xcite and independently turaev @xcite in an attempt to generalize the jones polynomial to links in general 3-manifolds , and have connections and applications to many interesting objects like character varieties , topological quantum field theories , quantum invariants , quantum teichmller spaces , and many others , see e.g. @xcite .",
    "the quotient @xmath5 , which is a @xmath6-algebra , is called the skein algebra at @xmath7 .    for @xmath8 let @xmath9 , the set of non - negative integers , and for @xmath10 let @xmath11 $ ] , the set of laurent polynomials with non - negative coefficients , i.e. the set of @xmath12-linear combinations of integer powers of @xmath1 .",
    "an @xmath13-algebra , where @xmath10 or @xmath8 , is said to be _ positive _ if it is free as an @xmath13-module and has a basis @xmath14 in which the structure constants are in @xmath15 , i.e. for any @xmath16 , the @xmath17-coefficient of the product @xmath18 is in @xmath15 .",
    "such a basis @xmath19 is called a _ positive _ basis of the algebra .    the important positivity conjecture of fock and goncharov @xcite states that @xmath20 is positive for the case @xmath10 and @xmath8 .",
    "the first case obviously implies the second .",
    "the second case , on the positivity over @xmath6 , was proved by d. thurston @xcite .",
    "moreover , d. thurston make precise the positivity conjecture by specifying the positive basis as follows .",
    "a _ normalized sequence of polynomials over @xmath13 _ is a sequence @xmath21 , such that for each @xmath22 , @xmath23 $ ] is a monic polynomial of degree @xmath22 .",
    "every normalized sequence @xmath24 over @xmath13 gives rise in a canonical way a basis @xmath25 of the @xmath13-module @xmath20 , see section [ sec : prelim ] .",
    "a sequence @xmath21 of polynomials in @xmath26 $ ] is _ positive over @xmath13 _ if it is normalized and the basis @xmath25 is a positive basis of @xmath20 , for any oriented surface @xmath2 .",
    "then d. thurston proved the following .",
    "the sequence @xmath27 of chebyshev s polynomials is positive over @xmath8 .    here in this paper , chebyshev s polynomials @xmath28",
    "are defined recursively by @xmath29 if @xmath30 is the constant polynomial 2 , then the above polynomials are chebyshev s polynomials of type 1 . here",
    "we have to set @xmath31 since by default , all normalized sequence begins with 1 .    d. thurston suggested the following conjecture , making precise the positivity conjecture .",
    "the sequence @xmath27 of chebyshev s polynomials is positive over @xmath0 .",
    "we will show    let @xmath8 or @xmath10 and @xmath32 be a sequence of polynomials in @xmath26 $ ] .",
    "if   @xmath24 is positive over @xmath13 , then @xmath33 is an @xmath15-linear combination of   @xmath34 . besides , @xmath35 .    for the case",
    "@xmath8 , this result complements well theorem [ r.thurston ] above , as they together claim that the sequence of chebyshev polynomials is the minimal one in the set of positive sequence over @xmath6 . for @xmath10 , our result says that the sequence of chebyshev polynomial should be the minimal positive sequence",
    ". a stronger version of theorem [ r.main1 ] is proved in section [ sec:2 ] .",
    "the positivity conjecture considered here is different from the one discussed in @xcite , which claims that every element of a certain basis is a @xmath12-linear combination of monomials of cluster variables .      _",
    "a marked surface _ is a pair @xmath36 , where @xmath2 is a compact oriented surface with ( possibly empty ) boundary @xmath37 and @xmath38 is a finite set in @xmath37 .",
    "g. muller @xcite defined the skein algebra @xmath39 , extending the definition from surfaces to marked surfaces . when @xmath8 , this algebra had been known earlier , and actually , the above mentioned result of d. thurston ( theorem  [ r.thurston ] ) was proved also for the case of marked surfaces . however , there are two types of basis generators of the skein algebras , namely loops and arcs , and one needs two normalized sequences of polynomials @xmath24 and @xmath40 to define an @xmath13-basis of the skein algebra @xmath39 . here",
    "@xmath24 is applicable to loops , and @xmath40 is applicable to arcs , see section [ sec : marked ] .",
    "a pair of sequences of polynomials @xmath41 are _ positive over @xmath13 _ if they are normalized and the basis they generate is positive for any marked surface .",
    "d. thurston result says that with @xmath42 , the sequence of chebyshev polynomials , and @xmath43 defined by @xmath44 , the pair @xmath41 are positive over @xmath6 .",
    "we obtained also an extension of theorem [ r.main1 ] to the case of marked surface as follows .",
    "let @xmath8 or @xmath10 .",

    "the author would like to thank d. thurston for valuable discussions .",
    "the author also thanks the anonymous referees for useful comments which in particular lead to the current , stronger formulation of theorem [ thm.1f ] .",
    "this work is supported in part by the nsf .      in section [ sec : prelim ]",
    "we recall basic facts about the kauffman bracket skein algebras of surfaces .",
    "we present the proofs of theorem  [ r.main1 ] and theorem  [ r.main2 ] in respectively section  [ sec:2 ] and section  [ sec : marked ] .",
    "we recall here basic notions concerning the kauffman bracket skein algebra of a surface .      throughout the paper we work with a ground ring @xmath13 which is more general than @xmath6 and @xmath0 .",
    "we will assume that @xmath13 is a commutative domain over @xmath6 containing an invertible element @xmath1 and a subset @xmath15 such that    * @xmath15 is closed under addition and multiplication * @xmath49 , and * @xmath50 .",
    "for example , we can take @xmath51 with @xmath7 and @xmath52 , or @xmath10 with @xmath53 $ ] .",
    "the reader might think of @xmath13 as one of these two rings .",
    "suppose @xmath2 is an oriented surface .",
    "the _ kauffman bracket skein module _",
    "@xmath20 is the @xmath13-module freely spanned by isotopy classes of non - oriented framed links in @xmath4 $ ] modulo the _ skein relation _ and the _ trivial loop relation _ described in figure [ fig : skein ] . in all figures ,",
    "framed links are drawn with blackboard framing .",
    "more precisely , the trivial loop relation says if @xmath54 is a loop bounding a disk in @xmath55 $ ] with framing perpendicular to the disk , then @xmath56 and the skein relation says @xmath57 if @xmath58 are identical except in a ball in which they look like in figure [ fig : skein1 ] .    for future reference",
    ", we say that the diagram @xmath59 ( resp .",
    "@xmath60 ) in figure [ fig : skein1 ] is obtained from @xmath54 by the positive ( resp .",
    "negative ) resolution of the crossing .",
    "the @xmath13-module @xmath20 has an algebra structure where the product of two links @xmath61 and @xmath62 is the result of stacking @xmath61 atop @xmath62 using the cylinder structure of @xmath4 $ ] . over @xmath8 ,",
    "the skein algebra @xmath20 is commutative and is closely related to the @xmath63-character variety of @xmath2 , see @xcite . over @xmath10 , @xmath20 is not commutative in general and is closely related to quantum teichmller spaces @xcite",
    ".      we will consider @xmath2 as a subset of @xmath64 $ ] by identifying @xmath2 with @xmath65 .",
    "as usual , links in @xmath2 , which are closed 1-dimensional non - oriented submanifolds of @xmath2 , are considered up to ambient isotopies of @xmath2 .",
    "a link @xmath66 in @xmath2 is _ an essential _ if it has no trivial component , i.e. a component bounding a disk in @xmath2 . by convention",
    ", the empty set is considered an essential link .",
    "the framing of a link is _ vertical _ if at every point @xmath67 , the framing is parallel to @xmath68 $ ] , with the direction equal to the positive direction of @xmath69 $ ] .    by (",
    "* theorem 5.2 ) , @xmath20 is free over @xmath13 with basis the set of all isotopy classes of essential links in @xmath2 with vertical framing .",
    "this basis can be parameterized as follows .",
    "integer lamination _ of @xmath2 is an unordered collection @xmath70 , where    * each @xmath71 is a positive integer * each @xmath72 is a non - trivial knot in @xmath2 * no two @xmath72 intersect * no two @xmath72 are ambient isotopic .    for each integer lamination @xmath73 ,",
    "define an element @xmath74 by @xmath75 then the set of all @xmath76 , where @xmath73 runs the set of all integer laminations including the empty one , is the above mentioned basis of @xmath20 .",
    "suppose @xmath21 is a normalized sequence of polynomials in @xmath26 $ ] .",

    "_ a framed 3d @xmath38-tangle @xmath66 in @xmath64 $ ] _ is a framed proper embedding of a 1-dimensional non - oriented compact manifold into @xmath64 $ ] such that @xmath159 $ ] , and the framing at every boundary point of @xmath66 is vertical .",
    "two framed 3d @xmath38-tangles are _ isotopic _ if they are isotopic through the class of framed 3d @xmath38-tangles .",
    "just like the link case , a framed 3d @xmath38-tangle @xmath66 is depicted by its diagram on @xmath2 , with vertical framing on the diagram . here",
    "a diagram of @xmath66 is a projection of @xmath66 onto @xmath2 in general position , with an order of strands at every crossing .",
    "crossings come in two types .",
    "if the crossing is in @xmath160 , then it is a usual double point ( with usual over / under information ) .",
    "if the crossing is a point in @xmath38 , there may be two or more number of strands , which are ordered .",
    "the order indicates which strand is above which .",
    "when there are two strands , the lower one is depicted by a broken line , see e.g. figure [ fig : arc ] .",
    "let @xmath39 be the @xmath13-module spanned by the set of isotopy classes of framed 3d @xmath38-tangles in @xmath64 $ ] modulo the skein relation , the trivial knot relation ( figure  [ fig : skein ] ) , and the trivial arc relation of figure  [ fig : arc ] .",
    "again one defines the product @xmath162 of of two skein elements @xmath61 and @xmath62 by stacking @xmath61 above @xmath62 .",
    "this makes @xmath39 an @xmath13-algebra , which was first defined by muller @xcite .",
    "_ a @xmath38-arc _ is an immersion @xmath163\\to \\sigma$ ] such that @xmath164 and the restriction of @xmath66 onto @xmath165 is an embedding into @xmath160 . _",
    "a @xmath38-knot _ is an embedding of @xmath166 into @xmath160 .",
    "a @xmath38-knot or a @xmath38-arc is _ trivial _ if it bounds a disk in @xmath2 .",
    "two @xmath38-arcs ( resp .",
    "@xmath38-knots ) are _ @xmath38-isotopic _ if they are isotopic in the class of @xmath38-arcs ( resp",
    ". @xmath38-knots ) .",

    "when the two ends of a @xmath38-arc are the same point @xmath167 , we order the left strand to be above the right one .      *",

    "these data are enough to determine the arc @xmath242 of @xmath238 containing @xmath240 , see figure [ fig : proof4 ] .",

    "this proves identity .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we show that the chebyshev polynomials form a basic block of any positive basis of the kauffman bracket skein algebras of surfaces . </S>"
  ]
}
